text:
In this video, you’ll see how you can 
publish Amazon Machine Images
(AMIs) in AWS Marketplace.
Why publish AMIs in AWS Marketplace?

A technical validation report from 
Enterprise Strategy Group (ESG),

found that AWS Marketplace features 
contribute to improve procurement
efficiency and increase compliance.

When you publish your AMI to AWS 
Marketplace, you don't have to worry

about cloning your AMI and hosting 
it in all the different AWS Regions
you want your AMI available in.

Your AMI also deploys into 
the customer's own account.

We’ll review the end-to-end publishing process, 
the AMI product types and their pricing models,

how billing and integration works, how 
to submit AMI products and metadata,

and how to review, test, 
and publish AMI products.

We’ll also discuss some common issues
that might arise and how to avoid them.

Let’s begin with an overview of 
the end-to-end publishing process.

As the seller of an AMI product, you’ll 
prepare the AMI in your AWS seller account.

You’ll submit the AMI for scanning in the
AWS Marketplace Management Portal.

Next, you’ll submit the product’s 
metadata and pricing information.

If you are using an AWS 
CloudFormation template for delivery,
include the location of the template.
AWS Marketplace then reviews your submitted materials and establishes
a limited listing URL for your product.

At this point, only authorized accounts can 
view and subscribe to the staged product.

Next, you’ll test the limited listing 
to ensure the subscribe and launch
processes works how you expect.

AWS Marketplace also tests your 
product for policy and security

compliance, software vulnerabilities, 
and product usability.

When both parties approve the limited 
listing, AWS Marketplace turns the

product to “live” in 
coordination with your schedule.

Next, let’s review the AMI 
product types and pricing models.

You can deliver your AMI-based product 
in one of three ways: as a Single AMI,

a Single AMI with a CloudFormation 
template, or as a Multi AMI
with CloudFormation template.

The pricing models available for 
Single AMIs and Single AMIs with
CloudFormation are the same.

With hourly pricing, AWS Marketplace 
automatically tracks the buyer’s hourly

usage for each Amazon 
EC2 instance used.

You can also offer buyers an upfront 
annual contract with a discount,
a free trial, or a private offer.

The monthly fixed pricing model 
charges buyers a monthly rate
regardless of their usage.

You can charge an additional 
hourly rate for EC2 instance usage,

but you cannot extend private 
offers with this model.
With a custom metering pricing model,

you can define up to 24 
dimensions on which to base costs.

For example, you can define the number 
of product users, or the amount of data
put through the EC2 instance.
You can also create private offers.

With contract pricing you can set a 
fixed upfront price for buyers’ usage

of dimensions within a 
specified contract period.

Private offers can be made 
with this pricing model.

The Multi AMI with CloudFormation 
product type supports only hourly

pricing at this time, and 
private offers cannot be made.

Next, we’ll review how 
billing and integration work.

The hourly and monthly pricing 
models, don’t require integration.

Instead, when you submit your AMI to 
AWS Marketplace, a product code is

attached that is used for automatic 
entitlement checks and billing.
The code tells EC2 to check with AWS

Marketplace to see if an account is 
subscribed before allowing the launch.

If it is, Marketplace authorizes the launch and 
tracks the hours used by the EC2 instances.

Note that if a buyer creates a copy of the
 AMI, the instances launched from that

derivative AMI will also be tracked by 
Marketplace using the product code.

To use the hourly or monthly pricing models, 
your AMI software must be fully functional

out of the box and not require that 
buyers purchase additional licenses.

The custom metering pricing 
model does require integration.

Once a buyer launches an 
EC2 instance from your AMI,

the software in your AMI sends an 
hourly MeterUsage API call that

communicates the quantities consumed
 for dimensions being tracked for usage

to the AWS Marketplace Metering 
Service, which then tabulates the cost.

The contract pricing model 
also requires integration.

After a contract is finalized, 
the buyer’s upfront entitlements

are stored with their AWS 
account in AWS License Manager.

When the buyer launches an 
EC2 instance from your AMI,

the software in your AMI makes a 
CheckoutLicense call to AWS License

Manager for confirmation of entitlement
 before it becomes functional.

Next, we’ll look at how to submit 
a product and its metadata.
Regardless of product type,

you’ll make a copy of the AMI and 
submit the image to AWS Marketplace.

If your product includes CloudFormation 
templates, you’ll submit them as well.

Before you begin the submission 
process, your AMI should be ready
in your AWS seller account, in EC2,

and stored in the us-east-1 Region so 
can be accessed by AWS Marketplace.
When ready to submit your AMI product,

visit the AWS Marketplace Management
 Portal and add the AMI asset.

Select your available AMIs from 
EC2 and move to the next step.

AWS Marketplace requires permission
to scan the AMI, so you’ll supply an

appropriate AWS Identity and 
Access Management (IAM) role.

Ensure the OS username and SSH 
port are accurate for your AMI.

Then you’ll wait as the 
scanning is performed.

Once the scan is 
complete, you can move on.

Next, you’ll create a server product and
identify which pricing model you will use.
Based on your selection here,

you’ll be directed to one of two paths 
for supplying product information.

You will fill out either an online form or
an Excel sheet, called a product load form

(PLF), and then load it back into the 
AWS Marketplace Management Portal.

You’ll use the online form if submitting a
Single AMI product that is free, charged

hourly, or charged hourly 
with an annual upfront option.

All others will require that 
you complete the PLF.

If you’re including a CloudFormation 
template with the product, you can
provide the template URL on the PLF.

If you’re not hosting it publicly, 
AWS Marketplace will reach out

to request the template after 
you’ve completed the submission.

Finally, we’ll go over the review, 
testing, and publishing steps.

Once your limited listing is created, 
you’ll have some back-and-forth

communication with AWS Marketplace 
regarding its compliance and readiness.
Here’s what AWS Marketplace reviews:

Your AMI can have no high or critical 
Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs),
no authorized keys or fixed default

passwords, and must use key-pair for 
SSH and not password authentication.

Additionally, you must allow 
operating system-level admin access.

This means if you’re using Linux, the root 
user must be accessible by the buyer.

The product is reviewed for compliance with 
security requirements and AMI policies.

Usage instructions must meet AWS 
Foundational Technical Review guidelines,

and any CloudFormation templates 
and diagrams must meet Marketplace
best practices and requirements.

Finally, AWS Marketplace will confirm 
the AMI product can successfully launch

in accordance with the provided usage 
instructions and that it is accessible.

There are some common issues sellers
 run into that you can anticipate and

avoid when submitting your AMI 
product for publication or remedy.

If high or critical CVEs are detected in
 the scan, you can review the results
and patch the packages accordingly.

Detection of authorized keys or OS 
passwords may prompt you to review

AWS resources on best practices and 
guidelines for cleaning AMIs for sharing.

Avoid using fixed default-administrative
 passwords by setting a random

password upon launch, such as the 
instance ID, which can be retrieved
from the Instance Metadata Service.

If you find the PLF confusing, you can 
refer to seller guides on AWS Marketplace

or contact the operations 
team with questions.

The PLF is a temporary measure 
while the submission process is
updated to become fully self-service.

CloudFormation templates must 
be compliant with AWS Marketplace
policies and best practices.

Please ensure you review the guidelines for 
CloudFormation templates before submitting.

After all resolutions are made and 
you’ve determined the product is good

to publish, you can inform AWS 
Marketplace to make the product listing live.

You’ve just seen how you can publish 
AMI products in AWS Marketplace.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it's your turn to try.
